name: Death in Various Cultures Online Quiz | Death Becomes Them | 15 Questions

questions.text: One of Willa Cather's most famous works is 'Death Comes for the ____________'.
In some legends, Death (the Grim Reaper) plays a fiddle with how many strings?
questions.explanation:
1.

	Arnold Boecklin did a painting illustrating this in the 1880s -- 'Self-Portrait with Death as the Fiddler.' It's a good painting. I recommend it.

questions.text: According to the Buddhist tradition, deceased people who have followed the Eightfold Path will be freed from the cycle of reincarnation and gain what state of total peace?
According to the King James version of the Twenty-Third Psalm, 'Yea, though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I shall fear no ___________'?
questions.explanation:
evil.

	This psalm is attributed to David.

questions.text: In the history of the United States of America, only four U.S. presidents have been assassinated. Who was the SECOND such president?
questions.explanation:
James Garfield.

	There is a theory that Zachary Taylor died from being poisoned, probably with arsenic in a bowl of cherries, but several years ago his body was exhumed and no trace of arsenic (which is relatively stable and would have remained in his bones) was discovered.

questions.text: In Shakespeare's 'Antony and Cleopatra,' and perhaps in history as well, with what did Cleopatra kill herself?
questions.explanation:
a venomous snake.

	Apparently, it was an asp.

questions.text: Shah Jahan of India built what famously beautiful building as a memorial to his favorite wife?
questions.explanation:
Taj Mahal.

	Shah Jahan emptied his treasuries to build the Taj Mahal, enabling one of his sons to seize power. He (the father) spent the last several years of his life imprisoned across from the Taj Mahal, gazing out at it from a narrow window.

questions.text: The Celtic queen, Boudicca (Boadicea), allegedly took poison to prevent torture by the Romans after they defeated her rebel forces in battle. Where is she thought to be buried?
questions.explanation:
King's Cross Station.

	Many archaeologists pin it down even further, saying that she is buried underneath Platform No. 9.

questions.text: Another Celtic leader -- who united Gaul under his command and came very close to defeating Julius Caesar -- did fall into Roman hands. He was brought back to Rome and executed by being dragged apart by wild horses. What was the name of this first French national hero?
questions.explanation:
Vercingetorix.

	Vercingetorix was a Celt, not a Frenchman in any modern sense, but the French claim him as a French hero, all the same.

questions.text: She had the great misfortune of living in Paris during the Reign of Terror, and she was forced to make death masks of the people who had been guillotined. Later she moved to Britain, and these death masks became the basis of a famous wax museum. She was Madame _________.
Robert Frost, perhaps best known among schoolchildren as the author of 'Stopping by Woods on a Snowy Evening,' also wrote a poem describing 'The Death of the ______________'
In Louisa May Alcott's 'Little Women', which March sister dies?
questions.explanation:
Beth.

	Laurie isn't a March sister. He's their neighbor.

questions.text: The European Middle Ages -- a time of war and plague -- was defined by death. One frequent artistic motif, representing death, depicted the Grim Reaper leading people away in the ______________.
Joan of Arc, maid of Orleans, was burned as a witch and a heretic by the English in what other French city during the Hundred Years' War?
questions.explanation:
Rouen.

	The charges were trumped up - she was canonized as a saint in 1920!

questions.text: What ancient Egyptian god, father of Horus, was murdered by his brother Seth and then became king of the Underworld?
questions.explanation:
Osiris.

	When Egyptian pharaohs died, they were said to have become Osiris -- kings of the underworld, in their turn.
